title_as_recorded: Şerh-i Sudi ber Divan-i Hoca Hafız Şirazî
title_as_recorded_agr: شرح سودي بر ديوان خواجة حافظ شيرازي
subject_as_recorded: Ḥāfiẓ, 14th cent. Dīvān--Criticism, Textual|Persian poetry--747-1500--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: 327 leaves : paper ; 212 x 147 (159 x 105) mm. bound to 212 x 160 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 2a.|23 lines per page. Written in medium small naskh in black ink with use of red. Text within a single-line frame in red ink, except for ff. 3b, 4a, 4b, 5b and 6a which are in gilt frame. Fol. 5b has a gilt heading. Ff. 323b-325b table of contents ruled in red ink (the commentary is arranged by letters of alphabet according to the ending of verses). Some marginal annotations. Foliation in Arabic numerals starts with 2 on fol. 5. Catchwords on the verso of each folio. European glazed paper. Fol. 10 has the text area cut out and replaced by a repair sheet on dark cream paper. Various inscriptions in a later hand, same pasted, on ff. 1a, 2a, 2b, 5a, 326a and 326b. A more concise table of contents in a later hand on fol. 1b. Ownership statement with a seal dated 1161 (1748), on fol. 5a. Inscription on the lower edge of text block: "Fārisī".

subject_as_recorded: Ḥāfiẓ, 14th cent. Dīvān--Criticism, Textual|Persian poetry--747-1500--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: 403 leaves : paper ; 290 x 185 (202 x 110) mm. bound to 295 x 195 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 1a.|31 lines per page. Written in small nastaʻlīq in black ink with use of red. Text within gilt frame, ruled in black ink and filled with gold leaf. Illuminated head-piece (ʻunwān) on fol. 1b, flower design in gold leaf and red, blue, orange and white watercolors. Margins throughout marked with short rubrication in red ink indicating where the commentary agrees with either Surūrī's or Şemi's commentary or both. Extensive marginal annotations on ff. 1b, 2a and 2b only. Catchwords on the verso of each folio. European glazed paper. A couple of ownership statements on fol. 1a, one of them with a seal and dated 1213 (1798-9).

subject_as_recorded: Turkish poetry--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: vii, 87, iii leaves : paper ; 205 x 105 (150 x 70) mm. bound to 215 x 115 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title supplied by the cataloger.|Incomplete: 1 leaf missing at the beginning and approximately 10 to 15 leaves at the end.|14 lines per page. Written in small nastaʻlīq in black ink with occasional use of red for rubrication. Text on fol. 1a within a frame outlined with brown ink and gold leaf, sections separated by areas in blue and brown ink, and gilt cloud-bands decorated with red, blue and yellow ink. The rest of the text within frames outlined in brown, or blue and brown ink and gold leaf. Verses within sections ruled in black and yellow ink. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Glazed paper with visible laid lines. Substantial damage and extensive repair to paper throughout with some loss of text. Modern foliation in pencil in Western numerals.

subject_as_recorded: Turkish poetry--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: 128 leaves : paper ; 184 x 118 (148 x 84) mm. bound to 184 x 120 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 4a.|14 lines per page. Written in elegant small nastaʻlīq in black ink. Text on ff. 4b and 5a within a double gilt frame, ruled in black ink and filled with gold leaf, the inner frame 1 mm and the outer 3 mm wide. The rest of the text within single gilt frame, ruled in black ink and filled with gold leaf, 3 mm wide. Verses within sections outlined in black ink and gold leaf. Fol. 11b has illuminated head-piece (ʻunwān), floral and geometrical design made with gold leaf and red, blue, green, yellow and purple watercolors. Text on ff. 11b and 12a within triple frame, outlined in black ink with the inner and outer sections of the frame filled with gold leaf and the middle with blue watercolor. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Dark cream paper with prominent fibres and faint laid lines, glazed. Modern foliation in pencil with Western numerals.|Ms. additions: numerous short notes and inscriptions in different hands on ff. 1, 2, 3, 4a, 125b, 126 and 127, mostly Fuzulî's verses and some ownership statements. Two inscriptions are dated, 1120 (1708/9) and 1153 (1740/41). Several ownership stamps on ff. 125-127.

subject_as_recorded: Turkish poetry--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: 106 leaves : paper ; 187 x 125 (137 x 80) mm. bound to 187 x 128 mm.

Text on ff. 2b and 3a within a gilt frame and gilt cloud-bands. The rest of the text within a double line gilt frame. Verses within sections outlined in black ink and gold leaf. All pages have a margin ruled in gold (172 x 110 mm). Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Thin glazed paper with visible laid lines.

subject_as_recorded: Muḥammad, Prophet, -632--Biography--Early works to 1800|Hadith--Commentaries--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: i, 179, i leaves : paper ; 188 x 110 (150 x 70) mm. bound to 188 x 115 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from colophon (fol. 177a).|Date from fol. 75a. The text is split in two parts and only the first part is dated.|Layout varies: first section has 27, and second has 21 lines per page; text frame for the first section measures 150 x 70 mm, and the second 127 x 53 mm. Written in small naskh in black ink with use of red. Text on fol. 2b and 3a within gold leaf frame ruled in black ink, with a simple rectangular gold leaf filled head piece on fol. 2b. Text on ff. 3b-75a within a single-line frame ruled in red ink. Text on fol. 78b and 79a within gold leaf frame ruled in black ink with a floral design gold leaf head piece on fol. 78b. Text on ff. 79b-177a within a single-line frame ruled in red ink. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Some marginal annotations in contemporary hand, chiefly in the first section of the text. Ff. 1 and 179 are flyleaves of thin cream paper with visible laid lines and a crown watermark. Ff. 2-77 on very thin light cream glazed paper with no visible chain or laid lines. Ff. 78-178 on darker glazed paper with faint laid lines and more prominet fibres.|Ms additions: 3 pages of verse on ff. 177b-178b in a later hand. A number of short inscriptions and ownership statements on ff. 1a, 2a, 177b and 179b. Some of the latter are accompanied with seals, and are dated variously from 1700 to 1858.|Copying of the first section of the text was completed on the 29th of Shaʻbān 1093 -- fol. 75a.|Originally acquired by Robert Garrett from Abraham Shalom Yahuda ; 1942.

physical_description: Extent: 133 leaves : paper ; 220 x 154 (147 x 83) mm. bound to 224 x 170 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 1b.|Added title on fol. 1a: Siyer-i Nebevî-yi Mekkî li-Veysî-yi Üskübî.|Date from fol. 128b: "tarih sqgh", i.e. 1160 (coversion table given on fol. 132a).|17 lines per page. Written in a casual medium small naskh in black ink with use of red. Illuminated ʻunwān on fol. 1b, made with gold leaf and red, blue and white watercolors. Text on fol. 1b and 2a within double gold leaf frames ruled in black ink, with use of gold leaf for breaks. Margins on fol. 1b and 2a outlined in gold leaf (205 x 145 mm). Two decorated marginal notes on fol. 1b and 2a, the first is within a rectangular panel outlined in gold leaf and green watercolor, with a gold, green, red and blue head piece, and the second is within a scalloped medallion shaped frame outlined in gold. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Few marginal annotations. Glazed European paper.|Ms additions: ff. 129b-130a: a note by the scribe dedicating the copy to his comrades fallen in battle; fol. 132a: alphabet table with numerical values of letters; fol. 133b: a short inscription listing a number of Ottoman military victories, with dates; fol. 133b (a flyleaf on a different, dark cream paper) has a recipe.|Copied by Mehmet Kahya-yi Defter ibn Mustafa Efendi in 1160.|Originally acquired by Robert Garrett from Abraham Shalom Yahuda ; 1942.

subject_as_recorded: Muḥammad, Prophet, -632--Biography--Early works to 1800|Hadith--Commentaries--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: i, 312, i leaves : paper ; 222 x 116 (166 x 74) mm. bound to 222 x 120 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 3a.|Title on the lower edge of text block: Siyer-i Veysî.|25 lines per page. Written in small nastaʻlīq, which at times changes into ruqʻah, in black ink with use of red, blue and gold. Beautifully executed illuminated ʻunwān on fol. 3b, consisting of a gold leaf filled rectangle with a scalloped edge head piece in flower pattern above, made with embossed gold leaf and red, blue, green, purple, orange, white and black watercolors. Similar, less elaborate illuminated ʻunwāns on fol. 81b and fol. 149b, both with a gold leaf filled rectangle with a scalloped edge flower design head piece above, made with embossed gold leaf and different watercolors. Text is within a gold leaf frame outlined in black ink. Glazed paper which varies throughout in thickness, fibres and color, and includes light cream, dark cream, yellow, red-tinted and dark blue paper. Most leaves are either sprinkled or speckled in silver ink, and some are decorated with flower and leaf motifs also in silver ink. Few marginal annotations. Table of contents for the first work on ff. 1b-2a in black and red ink. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf.|Originally acquired by Robert Garrett from Abraham Shalom Yahuda ; 1942.

Evidence of an obliterated inscription in silver ink, repaired with a piece of paper with a crescent and star motif on fol. 1a.

subject_as_recorded: Poets, Turkish--Biography--Early works to 1800|Poets--Islamic Empire--Biography--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: 234 leaves : paper ; 256 x 150 (168 x 80) mm. bound to 260 x 155 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title supplied by the cataloger.|23 lines per page. Written in small naskh in black ink with use of red, blue, green and gold ink for rubrication. Text within gold leaf frame outlined in black and grey ink. From fol. 123 onwards the text is written within the frame and expanded on the margins, possibly as a result of collation. Verses within the text separated by gold leaf frames outlined in black ink. Illumination on fol. 1a: a circle with scalloped edges in floral pattern made in gold, green, blue, orange and purple ink. Illuminated ʻunwān on fol. 1b consisting of a rectangular gold leaf panel with geometrical and floral patterns in blue, red, green and black watercolors, and a scalloped edge head piece above it, also in gold leaf, with blue, red and green watercolors. Paper on fol. 1b and 2a decorated with foliage pattern in gold ink. Floral tail piece on fol. 234a in gold and black ink. Paper varies and includes at least two different types, one is thick dark cream glazed paper with visible chain lines, and the other is a thin glazed paper with no visible chain lines and with prominent fibres. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Several inscriptions, including notes about the author, some verse and ownership statements, on front pastedown, the verso of front flyleaf and fol. 1a and fol. 234b.|Originally acquired by Robert Garrett from Abraham Shalom Yahuda ; 1942.

subject_as_recorded: Poets, Turkish--Biography--Early works to 1800|Poets--Islamic Empire--Biography--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: iii, 233, iii leaves : paper ; 186 x 97 (175 x 80) mm. bound to 186 x 105 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title supplied by the cataloger.|Incomplete.|21 lines per page (within main frame). Written in small nastaʻlīq in black ink with use of red for rubrication. All pages except for the first 6 folios have a gold leaf frame outlined in black ink and a gold leaf margin outlined in black ink. Text is written within both the frame and the margin, in the following pattern: frame of recto, margin of recto, frame of verso, margin of verso etc. Thin dark cream glazed paper with prominent fibres and visible chain and laid lines. Ff. 1-6 are later replacement sheets in different hand and on a different, light cream paper. Fol. ia marked "ʻadad 79".|Originally acquired by Robert Garrett from Abraham Shalom Yahuda ; 1942.

physical_description: Extent: 259 leaves : paper ; 198 x 133 (150 x 82) mm. bound to 200 x 135 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title supplied by the cataloger.|Ms. additions: Numerous inscriptions on front and back flyleaves (ff. 2a-6a, 9b,10a, 248b-259a), in different paper to the main body of the manuscript and consisting of fetvas, many of them by Ebussuud Efendi, a number of quotations, and verse. One of these, several lines of poetry on fol. 254b, is dated 1053 (1643-44), which means that at least some of the flyleaves were already inscribed when they were added at binding. Ff. 6b, 8b and 9a have a table of contents for the main text. physical_description: Extent: i, 298, i leaves : paper ; 218 x 126 (158 x 75) mm. bound to 218 x 132 mm.
note: Ms. composite codex.|Title from the lower edge of text block.|Main text was copied by Derviş Mehmet Ahlakî on the 15th of Shaʻbān 997 (1589), this being the 30th copy which he did -- colophon (fol. 261b). Given the dedication to Sultan Abdülhamid I, the second and third texts, which are written continuously, are from the 18th century and were subsequently bound with the first.|Main text: 19 lines per page. Written in small nastaʻlīq in black ink with use of red for rubrication. Text is written within a gold leaf frame outlined with three lines in black ink, with headings and verses in separately outlined sections. Fol. 6b has an illuminated head piece (ʻunwān) made in gold leaf with dark and light blue, orange and purple watercolors. Fol. 6b, 12a, 21a, and then every 10th leaf has a circular medallion on the margin, made with gold leaf with foliage pattern in black ink in the center with red circle around it and blue ink around the edges. Fol. 112b-116a have margins sprinkled in gold. Glazed dark cream paper with visible laid lines and prominent fibres. Foliation in Arabic numerals in red ink starts with 1 on fol. 7. Texts 2 and 3: 11 lines per page. Written in medium small nastaʻlīq in black ink with use of red. Text written within a single line frame outlined in red ink. Very thin light cream glazed paper with visible laid lines and prominent fibres.|Ms. additions: Several short inscriptions on fol. 1b; table of contents on fol. 2b-3a; two ownership statements on fol. 6a, one in the name of Mehmet Celaleddin, accompanied by a stamp dated 189 (1775-76), and the other in the name of Ömer Hüsameddin, dated 26 M 1227 (10 February 1812).|Originally acquired by Robert Garrett from Abraham Shalom Yahuda ; 1942.

Written in medium small naskh in black ink with use of red for rubrication. Text is written in two columns, with verses written within one column first and then continuing to the other. Text is inside a frame outlined with one line of red ink, and columns are separated by two lines of red ink, except on ff. 6b-7a where the frame and the lines are in gold leaf outlined in black ink, with gold circles inside the text at the beginning and end of each couplet. Fol. 6b has an illuminated head piece in gold leaf with red, blue and orange watercolors. Glazed European paper. An ownership inscription in black ink on fol. 6a, in the name of Mehmet Sadik.

note: Ms. codex.|Title from ʻunwān on fol. 2b.|Copied by Ismail Raif, [an employee?] in the Court Chambers in Edirne, and completed on the 6th of Rajab 1212 -- colophon (fol. 72a).|17 lines per page. Half of the ms. is written in small naskh (fol. 2-29) and half in small taʻlīq (fol. 30-72) in black ink with use of red. Text is written inside a single-line frame in red ink, with verses inside the frame also separated in red ink. Fol. 2b-3a have wide frames made with two lines of gold leaf with a foliage pattern in gold ink between them. The frames are outlined in black ink and have one line of red on the outside. The same ff. also have the gold pattern and two lines of gold leaf between the two columns of text. Fol. 2b has an illuminated head piece (ʻunwān) made with a floral pattern in gold ink. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Glazed European paper. Fol. 1b-2a have several short inscriptions, chiefly couplets of verse.|Originally acquired by Robert Garrett from Abraham Shalom Yahuda ; 1942.

physical_description: Extent: 93 leaves : paper ; 175 x 115 (125 x 66) mm. bound to 175 x 118 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title supplied by the cataloger.|Copied by the dervish Seyit Abdülkerim Rufai, a disciple of the Sheikh Seyit Ali Rufai, of the Kapan[?] Hanekâh in Sofia ("bi-khānaqāh-i Qapān Ṣūfīyawī"), and completed on the 27th of Jumādá al-Ūlá 1238 (1823) -- colophon (fol. 91a).|19 lines per page. Written in a small naskh in black ink with use of red and gold for rubrication. Text is written inside a gold leaf frame outlined in three lines of black and one line of red ink. All headings and verses or important lines of text are enclosed in guilt head pieces, sometimes forming cloud bands. Fol. 1b-2a have wider text frames made with two gold leaf lines with a line in orange watercolor in between. Fol. 1b has a beautiful head piece executed in embossed gold leaf with light and dark orange, red, and blue watercolors. Fol. 1b-2a also have guilt medallions in the margins, made with embossed gold leaf surrounded by floral pattern in blue, orange and red watercolors, and radiating sprigs along the vertical axis in blue and red watercolors. Final lines of text on fol. 91a are enclosed in guilt head pieces, and the colophon is inside a triangular tail piece, with the empty area of the frame around it filled with a floral pattern drawn in gold ink. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Glazed European paper.

subject_as_recorded: Süleyman I, Sultan of the Turks, 1494 or 1495-1566|Turkey--History--1453-1683--Early works to 1800|Turkey--History--Süleyman I, 1520-1566--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: 200 leaves : paper ; 270 x 150 (202 x 194) mm. bound to 270 x 155 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title supplied by the cataloger.|Copied by Sayyid al-Ḥājj Yūsuf Nādirī, one of the clerks in the Office of the Silahdar, in 1199 (1784 or 1785) -- colophon (fol. 199a).|25 lines per page. Written in medium small naskh in black ink with use of red for rubrication. Text is within a gold leaf frame outlined in black ink. On ff. 2b and 3a the frame is double, with an illuminated head piece on fol. 2b, made with gold leaf and blue, red, orange and yellow watercolors. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Foliation in Arabic numerals, starting on fol. 3. Glazed European paper. Fol. 2a has table of contents in a later hand, and two obliterated incriptions, one of which is an ownership statement, accompanied by a likewise obliterated seal.

note: Ms. codex.|Title from the beginning of the text on fol. 2b.|23 lines per page. An elegant copy, written in small nastaʻlīq in black ink with use of red for rubrication. Text is within a gold leaf frame outlined in black ink. Fol. 2b has a small gold leaf head piece (ʻunwān). Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Glazed European paper. Fol. 10a contains an unsigned note about the birth of an owner's son at 6 o'clock on Sunday evening, the 10th of Shawwāl 1226 (the 10th of Shawwāl 1226 fell on Monday, the 28th of October 1811, which means that he is referring to the eve of that date and the date is thus the 27th of October 1811).|Originally acquired by Robert Garrett from Abraham Shalom Yahuda ; 1942.

Text on ff. 2a and 3b within a gold leaf frame outlined in black and red ink. The rest of the text is within a single line frame outlined in red ink. Fol. 2b has a floral head piece in gold ink. subject_as_recorded: Turkish poetry--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: 117 leaves : paper ; 208 x 130 (160 x 87) mm. bound to 208 x 134 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 2b.|17 lines per page. Elegant copy, written in small naskh in black ink with some use of red. Verses are written within a frame divided into sections. The frame and sections on ff. 2b and 3a are in gold leaf outlined in black ink. The frame and sections in the rest of the text are outlined in single line of red ink. A beautiful head piece with title (ʻunwān) on fol. 2a, executed in gold leaf and dark blue water color as background to a foliage pattern in light blue and gold ink. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Glazed European paper in different colors, chiefly cream, but some are painted yellow and some blue. Foliation in Arabic numerals in black ink, starts on fol. 3. Several short inscriptions, some verse and ownership statements on ff. 1a-2a, one dated 1189 (1775 or 6). Several short inscriptions, and an ownership statement (in red ink) in the name of al-Sayyid al-Qāḍī Ismāʻīl Baḥrī on fol. 117a. Seven ownership seals on same fol., six of which are octagonal, five the same and one smaller, and one almond-shaped. Ownership statement and signature by Ḥusayn Mawtī, dated 1103 (1691 or 2) on fol. 117b.|Originally acquired by Robert Garrett from Abraham Shalom Yahuda ; 1942.

subject_as_recorded: Turkish poetry--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: 219 leaves : paper ; 206 x 142 (150 x 90) mm. bound to 207 x 153 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 2a.|Copied by Ibrahim Efendi, known as the kâtip of the late Ahmet, "Kethüda Parmaksız Müstahfızân", and completed in the last 10 days of Shaʻbān 1127 (1715).|17 lines per page. Written in medium small naskh in black ink with use of red for headings. Ff. 2b-5a have text within a frame outlined in red ink, and the rest of the text is without the frame. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Glazed European paper. An ownership statement with a faint seal, undated, on fol. 1a. A short inscription and an ownership statement on fol. 2a, the latter dated 1168 and accompanied by a signature and a round seal with floral pattern and 'ʻAlī' in the centre.

physical_description: Extent: 220 leaves : paper ; 230 x 155 (178 x 108) mm. bound to 238 x 160 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 1b.|Copied by Derviş Ahmet Bâhir Baba Kirimî, completed on the 11th of Ṣafar [?] 1250 (1834) -- colophon (fol. 214b).|19 lines per page. Written in medium small naskh in black ink with use of red. Verses written within a frame divided into sections, outlined in red ink. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Glazed European paper. Pagination in Arabic numerals in brown glitter ink. The date in colophon followed by "150, 12-[?] M. [malzamah?]". Four ownership statements around the colophon on fol. 214b, all in the same hand and mentioning second, third and fourth owners (ṣaḥib thānī etc.): Ibrāhīm Rushdī bin Muḥammad Arzanjānī, dated 1270 (1853 or 4), Ismāʻīl Pāshah al-Khidīwī, the Khedive of Egypt, dated 1305 (1887 or 8), a derviş Ismāʻīl Ḥaqqī bin Muḥammad Charkasī, Cairo, dated 1314 (1896 or 7), and finally, a statement to the effect that the fourth owner got the book from Ismāʻīl Ḥaqqī, dated again 1314 (1896 or 7). Additional verses in the same hand on fol. 215. Verses and a short text in a different hand on ff. 217 and 218.|Originally acquired by Robert Garrett from Abraham Shalom Yahuda ; 1942.

subject_as_recorded: Jāmī, 1414-1492. Muʻammayāt asmāʾ al-ḥusná|Arabic alphabet--Religious aspects--Islam--Early works to 1800|Arabic alphabet--Religious aspects--Sufism--Early works to 1800|Arabic alphabet--Symbolic aspects--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: i, 108 leaves : paper ; 202 x 150 (146 x 85) mm. bound to 204 x 155 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from colophon on fol. 104b. Other title from VOHD (see ref. below).|The colophon states that the work was copied by Ahmet Rifat bin Abdülkerim, a çavuş at the "el-Cami el-Kebir", in 1303 (1885-86) -- colophon (fol. 104b). However, this almost certainly does not apply to the entire ms, as the first page (fol. 2) and fol. 98-104 are later replacements in a different hand and on different paper, while the bulk of the text is in a completely different hand and on older paper.|The bulk of the ms. has 19 lines per page, is written in a small, casual siyāqat in black ink with use of red for rubrication. The later replacements also have 19 lines per page, but are written in a small casual naskh in black ink with use of red for rubrication. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. The older part of the ms. is on glazed paper with watermarks, the replacements are on cream wove paper. Following the colophon are six pages of verse (on fol. 105a-108a) in the same hand as the replacement pages of the main text; these have their own colophon on fol. 108a: written on the 27th of Shawwāl 1303 in the town of Kānāyīs [Egypt?].|Originally acquired by Robert Garrett from Abraham Shalom Yahuda ; 1942.

Worm damage to paper throughout.|Originally acquired by Robert Garrett from Abraham Shalom Yahuda ; 1942.

subject_as_recorded: Muḥammad, Prophet, -632--Character--Early works to 1800|Muḥammad, Prophet, -632--Poetry--Early works to 1800|Muḥammad, Prophet, -632|Turkish poetry--Early works to 1800|Devotional poetry, Turkish--Early works to 1800|Islamic poetry--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton|Poésie islamique--Ouvrages avant 1800|Manuscrits turcs--New Jersey--Princeton|Character|Islamic poetry|Manuscripts, Turkish|Poetry|Turkish poetry|New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: 245 leaves : paper ; 214 x 150 (138 x 86) mm bound to 214 x 158 mm.
note: Ms. composite codex.|Title from an added contents note on fol. 1a.|The two works are of different dates: they are in different styles, hands and on different paper. Text 1 has 23 lines per page and is written in small naskh in black ink with use of red for rubrication. Text 2 has 17 lines per page and is written in a medium sized naskh in black ink with use of red for rubrication. Both texts are on light glazed papers, with the one in text 1 being frame ruled with diagonal margins. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Fol. 1a has "145" in Arabic numerals in gold glitter ink, followed by a short paragraph on the contents of the ms. Title on the lower edge of text block: "Divan-i Hikmetî Ismail Efendi" and " Şerh-i hasayıs-i Nebi".|Originally acquired by Robert Garrett from Abraham Shalom Yahuda ; 1942.

physical_description: Extent: 146 leaves : paper ; 210 x 140 (145 x 80) mm bound to 210 x 140 mm.
note: Ms. composite codex.|Title from fol. 1a (dated 1161 (1748)?).|Fol. 1a has a list of months below the title in a different hand. A couple of inverted inscriptions in large naskh (verses) between texts 3 and 4 on fol. 74b-75a. Fol. 107a has a short inscription about the 28 prophets in the Qur'an. Fol. 144b contains a whole page of text, again on prescriptions of faith, which looks like a misplaced part of a larger work (similar in style to text 6). Two inverted inscriptions (one of them al-Fātiḥah) on fol. 145b.|Origin: [Treatise on the principles of piety] signed by the scribe: Mehmet bin Mustafa [from ?] (colophon, fol. 106b) -- [Treatise on trade ethics] Dated 1140 (colophon, fol. 144a). All texts are written in same style and similar hand, and most are written continuously (i.e. one ends and next one begins on same page), so they are possibly all by the same scribe and this date refers to the completion of the entire collection.|Layout: 19 lines per page.|Description: Partially rubricated ; three different types of glazed European paper.|Statement of vakıf in the name of Hacı Ali, the son of Kazancı Hacı Hasan, dated 29th of Ramaḍān 1270 (1854), on fol. 145b.

subject_as_recorded: Turkish poetry--Early works to 1800|Sufi poetry, Turkish--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton|Manuscripts, Turkish|Sufi poetry, Turkish|Turkish poetry|New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: 103 leaves : paper ; 212 x 164 (165 x 105) mm bound to 212 x 164 mm.
note: Ms. composite codex.|Title from lower and upper edges of text block.|Ms. additions: 1 loose sheet with a talisman in black ink: 3 large concentric circles in the middle, with series of numbers in the centre with invocations around them; surrounded by 7 small circles, each with different combinations of the words Allāh and Muḥammad. 1 loose, folded sheet with a letter, in Arabic, from Muḥammad al-Mahdī al-Sanūsī (1844-1902), the son of Muḥammad ibn ʻAlī al-Sanūsī (1787-1859) and leader of the Sanūsī order in Libya founded by his father, to Shaykh Muḥammad Yāsīn. The letter itself is dated Shaʻbān 1304 (1887), but is then followed by an inscription containing the name al-Sayyid Muḥammad ibn al-Sanūsī al-Mahdī and date 1276 (1859-60) [referring to his father and the date of his death?].|Layout: 27 lines per page.|Description: Rubricated ; written in a medium small taʻlīq with elements of ruqʻah in black ink. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Two different types of glazed European paper.|Origin: Both main texts and the short preliminary text appear to be in the same hand. Text 2 is signed by the scribe and dated: copied by Derviş Ebubekir in 1202 (1787-88) -- colophon text 2 (fol. 27b). The ink and the paper in text 3 are different and thus, although possibly written by the same scribe, the text is probably of a slightly later date.|Ownership signature, accompanied by a faint circular stamp in blue ink, in the name of Süleyman Efendi on fol. 1a. Same stamp on fol. 2a. Another stamp in black ink on fol. 2b.|Ownership statement in the name of Derviş Ahmet Efendi, dated Rabīʻ al-Awwal [?] 1336 (Dec. 1917-Jan. 1918), on fol. 28a. Same fol. has a completely obliterated stamp of a previous owner, and the same of fol. 28b.

subject_as_recorded: Turkish poetry--Early works to 1800|Sufi poetry, Turkish--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: 75 leaves : paper ; 205 x 142 (145 x 95) mm. bound to 205 x 142 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 2b.|Copied by Ibrahim bin Ali and completed in the last 10 days of Ramaḍān 1127 (1715) -- colophon (fol. 66a).|Ca. 16 lines per page. Written in a medium naskh with elements of ruqʻah in black ink. Text is written in a single raw of 7, 8 or 10 interlocking couplets (i.e. alternating between right and left handside). Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Thick, glazed European paper.|Ms. additions: Fol. 2a has an abjad table of letters with their corresponding numerical values. End of the text on fol. 66a is followed by a short note, in what appears to be the same hand, concerning a Kapıcıbaşı Çelebi Seyit Fehmi Mehmet Aǧa and the date March 1103/1692 (date of his death?). Fol. 66b-69b have an added text in Arabic in ʻIlm al-Ḥurūf, written diagonally accross the pages in a later hand in medium large naskh (some other copies of this divan have similar texts included in them, e.g. see GHB copies 2739 and 2741). Fol. 70b has two inscriptions, both records of births, dated 24 Dhū al-Qaʻdah 1132 (1720) and 29 Ṣafar 1142 (1729), both in black ink laced with gold glitter. Fol. 71b-72a have short versified inscriptions, in Ottoman, apparently again related to ʻIlm al-Ḥurūf (words are accompanied by numbers and dates relating to them). Fol. 74b has one inscription (verses) written twice, dated '220 and 13 Shawwal '225 (1810).|Ownership signature in the name of el-Hac İbrahim, dated 1215 (1800-01) on fol. 2a.|Originally acquired by Robert Garrett from Abraham Shalom Yahuda ; 1942.|Acquired from Abraham Shalom Yahuda.

subject_as_recorded: Sufism--Doctrines--Early works to 1800|Metaphysics--Early works to 1800|Ontology--Early works to 1800|God (Islam)--Doctrines--Early works to 1800|Creation (Islam)--Early works to 1800|Dervishes--Customs and practices--Early works to 1800|Dervishes--Conduct of life--Early works to 1800|Sufism--Rituals--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton|Manuscripts, Arabic--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: 79 leaves : paper ; 208 x 150 (115 x 80) mm. bound to 210 x 158 mm.
note: Ms. composite codex.|Title suplied by the cataloger.|Ms. additions: several short inscriptions on fol. 1a, 1b and 2a.|Layout: 15-30 lines per page.|Description: Written in a medium general script with elements of ruqʻah, or in nastaʻlīq ; rubricated ; text 11 is written diagonally across the page.|Origin: Text 7 (Ādāb al-fuqarāʼ) has a colophon from which the name of the scribe has been deleted but the date remains: 1191 (1777) -- colophon text 7 (fol. 63a). Text 8 (Deveran-i Sufiye'nin cevazine müteallik risale) is the same such that the name of the scribe has been completely obliterated but the date was left: Jumādá al-Ūlá 1191 (1777) -- colophon text 8 (fol. 69). These two texts as well as the the preceeding main texts (texts 1 and 4) are in the same hand and this would suggest that the whole collection was written or at least put together at the same time. Exception to this are texts 10 and 11 which are markedly different (different hand and style) and could be later additions.|A large square ownership stamp in the name of the Halveti Şeyh and Hafız, Mehmet Rizauddin Üsküdarî, from the lodge of Ahmet Efendi in Üsküdar, bearing the date '260 (1844-45), twice on fol. 2a and then repeated several times throughout the ms. A smaller circular stamp in the same name, with the date 1238 (1822-23), on fol. 2a and on fol. 2b. Another small, square stamp in the same name, with the date 1257 (1841-42), also on fol. 2a. The same fol. (2a) contains an inscription concerning Şeyh Mehmet Rizauddin dated 4th of Dhū al-Qaʻdah 1249 (1834). Above that on the same fol. is a statement of vakıf (no name mentioned) dated 1260 (1844-45).

subject_as_recorded: Jazūlī, Muḥammad ibn Sulaymān, -1465. Dalāʼil al-khayrāt|Muḥammad, Prophet, -632--Early works to 1800|Hadith--Early works to 1800|Islam--Prayers and devotions--Early works to 1800|Prayer--Islam--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: 362 leaves : paper ; 308 x 190 (238 x 130) mm. bound to 310 x 200 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title supplied by the cataloger.|Copied by Hafız Osman bin Davut and completed on 11 of Muḥarram 1172 (1758) -- colophon (fol. 362b). Between this and the end of text (see explicit) is what appears to be another colophon (starts with "qad tamma hādhā al-kitāb ...") with the date 17 of Rajab 116? [the word covered with paper repair] (1747-1756). This is in exactly the same hand and perhaps refers to the completion of the writing of the text while the second colophon refers to the final finishing touches, decoration etc.?|31 lines per page. Written in a medium naskh in black ink with some use of red for rubrication. Text is written inside a single line frame in red ink. The frames on fol. 1b, 2a and 362b are in wide gold leaf outlined in black ink. Fol. 1b has an illuminated head piece executed in gold leaf with orange, red, purple, green and white watercolors, and has gold circles for breaks inside the text. Fol. 362b has a double tail piece decorated with gold ink and also has gold circles inside the text. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Glazed European paper. Pagination in pencil in Arabic numerals. Substantial water damage and some repairs to the paper at the start and end of the ms.

physical_description: Extent: i, 173 leaves : paper ; 207 x 137 (139 x 77) mm. bound to 210 x 145 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 4b.|Copied by the Nakşibandi Şeyh İsmail of Osman Pazarı and completed on 23 Jumādá al-Ūlá [?] 1243 (1827) -- colophon (fol. 153b).|17 lines per page. Written in a medium small ruqʻah with elements of nastaʻlīq in black ink with some use of red for rubrication. Text is written inside a gold leaf frame outlined in black ink. On fol. 4b-5a the frame is double with green watercolor between the two frames and all is further outlined in one line of red ink. A small gold leaf ʻunwān on fol. 4b. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Glazed European paper. Pagination in Arabic numerals in black ink (incomplete). Foliation in pencil in Western numerals. Fol. 2b-3a have a table of contents in black ink, inside a gold leaf frame outlined in black ink and ruled in red ink. Fol. 169b-172a have the gold leaf text frames, but are left blank. Date 21 of Ṣafar 1292 (1875) on fol. 4a (in same hand and ink as in the table of contents and pagination).|Illuminations:|1. Fol. 4b-5a: illuminated text frames consisting of double gold leaf frames with the space between them filled with green watercolor and the whole outlined in one line of red ink. Small scalloped edged ʻunwān in gold leaf on fol. 4b.|2. Illuminated graphic presentation of a Nakşibandi şecere: begins with 2 illuminated panels on fol. 52b-53a consisiting of gold leaf frames outlined in black and red ink, floral corner pieces in gold ink and green, orange, purple and blue watercolors, and central circles in gold leaf, purple and green watercolors, with caligraphic inscriptions (in large naskh in black ink) of "Allāh" and "Muḥammad" inside each of the circles; continues from fol. 53b to 67a, in the form of linked circles in gold leaf and either left blank or filled with yellow, green, blue or red watercolors, with the names of each of the personages in the chain written in calligraphic inscriptions inside the circles (in large naskh in black ink), ending on fol. 67a with Şeyh İsmail Efendi of Osman Pazarı in the final circle (the copyist of the ms. - see colophon note above).

subject_as_recorded: Prophets--Charts, diagrams, etc.--Early works to 1800|Prophets--Genealogy--Early works to 1800|Prophets--Islamic Empire--Genealogy--Charts, diagrams, etc.--Early works to 1800|Kings and rulers--Islamic Empire--Genealogy--Early works to 1800|Turkey--History--Ottoman Empire, 1288-1918--Kings and rulers--Genealogy--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: 36 leaves : paper ; 290 x 195 (220 x 195) mm. bound to 290 x 200 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from beginning of text on fol. 2a. Other title from fol. 1a.|The work consists of an introduction, which is followed by a chart made of linked circles for each of the personages in the chain. The circles are outlined in red and green or just red, and some are also in black laced with gold glitter (that of the Prophet and those immediately around him). Each of the circles is accompanied by some text outside it. The names are in either red or black, and the text is chiefly in black. Written in a small naskh with elements of ruqʻah in black ink with use of red. Glazed European paper. The text also contains a ṣalāt istikhārah on fol. 3a, between the introduction and the beginning of the chart on fol. 3b, in a different hand to the rest of the ms. This is written in a slightly larger, more formal naskh, it is signed Mehmet Muhsin [Jubaynah?] Zade Efendi, and dated 7 Dhū al-Ḥijjah 1241 (1826). Fol. 35b-36a, after the end of the main text, have an addition also in a different hand consisting of a list of important Islamic conquests and a list of Ottoman Sultans after Selim II, with whom the main chart ends, with their dates of accession, ending with Selim III (1789-1807), so this was added during the latter's reign.|Ownership signature in the name of Hafız Mehmet Emin, accompanied by a stamp, on fol. 1a.

note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 1a.|Written in a form of a table, with around 20 lines per page. The table is outlined in red ink and the text is in small naskh in black ink, with red ink for headings and rubrication. Foliation in Arabic numerals in black ink, starts on fol. 2. Glazed European paper. Fol. 1a has a paragraph of introduction attributed to İbrahim Müteferrika, who published the work in 1773, and is thus also a later addition to the original copy. Fol. 2a has a signature of Aḥmad "known as" Köprülüzade, accompanied by a seal and dated 1140 (1727-8), and two ownership statements accompanied by seals and dated 1174 (1760-61) and Rajab 1218 (1803).

subject_as_recorded: Sufism--Early works to 1800|Sufi poetry, Turkish|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: i, 207, v leaves : paper, ill. ; 314 x 198 (253 x 137) mm. bound to 320 x 207 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Physical description: 24 lines per page; written in naskh in black mostly on glazed, laid Russian paper. The heavier paper bears the watermarks "A O 1814" and a lion set within an oval that is topped by a crown (similar to 1813 watermark in Z. V. Uchastkina, A history of Russian hand-paper mills and their watermarks, Hilversum 1962, no. 582), while on the thinner paper are the watermarks "A O 1812" and a coat of arms with the letters A O underneath (similar to Uchastkina, no. 673); fol. 186-204 bear a pro patria watermark (Uchastkina, no. 743). Fol. 21-38, 43-44 on wove paper bearing the watermarks "U I L P" and "1811." Fol. 78-85 on wove paper bearing the watermark "J Larking 1807." Texts 2, 4 in two columns; some poems in text 2 written on a diagonal. Rubrication in brown; catchwords. Fol. 1b, 2b, 8b-11b, 30b, 53b, 87b-88a, 114b, 127b-128b, 172b blank. Some staining. In good condition.|Origin: Text 3 completed on 28 Dhū al-Qaʻdah 1229 H [11 November 1814] by Abdülvahid ibn-i Süleyman Ahunde oǧlu in Saint Petersburg (fol. 172a). After the colophon another note is inscribed giving the date according to the "Roman" calendar as 29 October 1814.|On fol. 207b, waqf notice of Tarhan Mulla Mehmet Amin Han Temirov in the Çutay Medrese [possibly referring to Chutay in the modern Republic of Tatarstan]; his seal, in Arabic and Cyrillic scripts and dated 1840, is found on fol. 13a, 127a, 207b.

subject_as_recorded: Finance, Public--Turkey--Early works to 1800|Finance, Public--Law and legislation--Turkey--Early works to 1800|Land tenure--Law and legislation--Turkey--Early works to 1800|Turkey--Officials and employees--Salaries, etc.--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: 53 leaves : paper ; 204 x 118 (157 x 68) mm. bound to 206 x 122 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 2b.|Copied in 1063 (1652-1653) -- colophon of main text on fol. 30a. Only this section is dated but the appendix is written continuously in the same style and in same hand.|23 lines per page. Written in a small naskh in black ink with use of red for rubrication. Text is written inside a frame outlined in one line of green ink, except on fol. 2b-3a where the frames are in gold leaf outlined in black ink. Fol. 2b has an illuminated head piece (ʻunwān), executed in gold leaf with green, orange, red, purple, pink and black watercolors, with the title in the centre in orange ink. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Glazed European paper. Fol. 2a has an oval stamp with a cross pattern forming triangles with an inscription inside each of them. The text ends with a table of Ottoman sultans and dates of their accessions to the throne (after the explicit on fol. 38b). The list is then completed in a different hand on fol. 39a. Fol. 39b-42b have the text frames ruled but are blank. Fol. 43a-52b are blank. Fol. 53a-b has a number of short inscriptions, including a short list of different Ottoman statesmen on fol. 53b.

subject_as_recorded: Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: 107 leaves : paper ; 163 x 92 (139 x 69) mm. bound to 168 x 105 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from spine.|17 lines per page. Written in small nastaʻlīq in black ink with occasional use of red. Text is written inside a frame made with gold leaf outlined in black ink, with columns and verses inside the frame also separated with gold leaf. Fol. 1b-2a are illuminated: fol. 1b has a head piece made in gold leaf and flower pattern in gold leaf and light blue, purple, orange and white watercolors on dark blue background; similar pattern between the columns and around separated verses on fol. 1b-2a; all verses on both fol. are in cloud-bands with gold leaf around them. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Cream paper with visible laid lines and prominent pulp. Paper is water and insect damaged, especially the illuminated pages at the start, and has been repaired (and rebound).

subject_as_recorded: Islam--Customs and practices--Early works to 1800|Worship (Islam)--Early works to 1800|Faith (Islam)--Early works to 1800|Salat--Early works to 1800|Prayer--Islam--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: 149 leaves : paper ; 178 x 110 (135 x 68) mm. bound to 178 x 114 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 1b. Other titles from the start of the text on fol. 3a, and from the label on the inside of upper cover.|13 lines per page. Written in a medium small naskh, fully vocalised, in black ink with use of red for rubrication. Text is written inside a gold leaf frame outlined in black ink. From fol. 132a to the end the gold frame is thinner and without the black ink outline. Fol. 1b has a simple illuminated head piece made with a horizontal rectangle filled with gold leaf, on the top of which are two vertical rectangles in the centre and a triangle on each side of those, all outlined in black ink and gold leaf and speckled in gold. The space between lines of text on fol. 1b also speckled in gold. The rest of the ms has small gold circles used for breaks in text, and small medallions in gold leaf with red watercolor on the margin of the verso of each 12th leaf. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Glazed European paper. Some repairs to paper in the second half of the ms.|Originally acquired by Robert Garrett from Abraham Shalom Yahuda ; 1942.

physical_description: Extent: 131 leaves : paper ; 265 x 155 (175 x 70) mm bound to 265 x 158 mm.
note: Ms. composite codex.|Title from 1a.|Fol. 1b-2b have the table of contents for the first collection of Feyzullah's fetvas (text 2); they are followed by the selection of fetvas by Menteşizade (text 1) on fol. 3a and 4a, which is interrupted by a separate single fetva on fol. 3b, written in the same hand as the main text, and signed "katabahu Aḥmad Sūqī". Fol. 89b-90b have the table of contents for the second collection of Feyzullah's fetvas (text 3); they are followed on fol. 91a by a short paragraph in verse, signed "katabahu al-faqīr al-Sayyid Fayḍ Allāh". This second collection is wrongly identifed on fol. 1a as Fetava-yi Kirmânî, and below that on same fol. as Fetava-yi Akkirmânî (possibly referring to Mehmet Akkirmânî (d. 1760) or Ali Akkirmânî Efendi (d. 1657), etc.). Kabīkaj (invocation against bookworms) on fol. 1a. Short inverted inscriptions in a later hand on fol. 131b.|Layout: 26-31 lines per page.|Description: All texts are in a very similar hand and style, they are all written in medium small nastaʻlīq in black ink with use of red for rubrication, though the style of the script in texts 1 and 3 tends more towards taʻlīq. There are marginal annotations throughout texts 2 and 3, chiefly additional fetvas. The annotations all appear to be in the same hand. Irregular catchwords present. Glazed (European?) paper with visible watermarks. Foliation in Arabic numerals in black ink. Substantial water damage to the paper, especially in text 3, with some loss of text, either the marginal annotations or the edges of the main text. Some repairs to the paper.|Ownership statement in the name of Mehmet Bahaüddin ... [?], accompanied by his stamp on fol. 1a. Partially visible ownership signature on fol. 1a (top left corner of the page, half of it torn off), in the name of Mehmet Salih.|Originally acquired by Robert Garrett from Abraham Shalom Yahuda ; 1942.

subject_as_recorded: Advisory opinions (Islamic law)--Early works to 1800|Islamic law--Sources--Early works to 1800|Fatwas--Turkey--Early works to 1800|Muslims--Conduct of life--Legal aspects--Islamic law--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: 150 leaves : paper ; 242 x 154 (178 x 70) mm. bound to 242 x 155 mm.
note: Incipit: الحمد لله الذى تفرد بالقدم والبقاء وتوحد بالعظمة والكبرياء|Explicit: هنوز فيص ويرلمديكى حضور عاليلرينه اعلام اولندى|Ms. codex.|Both titles from the introduction (in Arabic) on fol. 13b-14a.|Copy completed on a Wednesday '45, i.e. 1245 (1829-30) -- margin of fol. 147b.|29 lines per page. Written in a small nastaʻlīq in black ink with use of red for rubrication. The introduction is in Arabic on fol. 13b-14a, and is written inside a double gold leaf frame outlined in black ink. Fol. 13b has an elegant illuminated head piece executed in gold ink with light purple and blue watercolors. Glazed European paper with frame-ruled margins, some of it (the second half of the ms.) re-glazed with egg-albumen. Fol. 13a has a short, original table of contents in black and red ink. Fol. 1-11 are a later addition on a thin wove paper and have a detailed table of contents in black and red ink in a different hand. "Şanizade" written on the lower edge of text block.|Originally acquired by Robert Garrett from Abraham Shalom Yahuda ; 1942.

language_as_recorded: Chiefly in Ottoman Turkish, with text 1 in Persian
physical_description: Extent: 229 leaves : paper ; 198 x 112 (150 x 65) mm bound to 198 x 125 mm.
note: Ms. composite codex.|Title from text 1 in the collection.|Description: All main texts (except the last section of poetry) are written in similar hand in black ink with use of red. Text 1 is written in small naskh, text 2 is in small siyāqat, and texts 3-5 are in a small, more casual script tending towards siyāqat. The excerpts of poetry at the end are of later dates and in a number of different hands, chiefly in taʻlīq and nastaʻlīq. Most texts have 21 lines per page. Texts 1 and 4 are written inside a single-line frame in red ink. Most texts have catchwords. Paper varies: some is glazed with visible chain lines, some is thicker, dark cream paper with only the laid lines visible, and some of it appears to be wove paper. Almond shaped stamp with scalloped edges with an inscription in Persian, on fol. 1a, 35b, and 131a.|Origin: [İbretnüma] Copy completed in the middle of Rabīʻ al-Ākhir 989 (1581) in "şehr-i Madinah al-Munīfah" (Medina?) -- colophon (fol. 129b).|Originally acquired by Robert Garrett from Abraham Shalom Yahuda ; 1942.

physical_description: Extent: i, 148, i leaves : paper ; 216 x 162 (160 x 95) mm. bound to 218 x 170 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 1a (a later addition in purple crayon).|Copied by Molla İbrahim bin el-hac Mehmet Remmah Zade, from Antakya, and completed in Rabīʻ al-Awwal 1164 (1751) -- colophon (fol. 148a).|21-23 lines per page. Written in a very casual small to medium small naskh in black ink with use of red for rubrication. From fol. 1 to fol. 42, the text starts off in one style, with written area more narrow and with more lines per page, after which it changes to less lines and the text is inside a frame outlined in a single line of red ink. After fol. 42 the paper changes too. The script in the first section is slightly larger, but the hand is not substantially different and could still be that of the scribe of the rest of the ms. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Glazed European paper with watermarks (some of the paper towards the end of the ms has frame-ruled margins). Several short inscriptions on front pastedown and fol. ia. An oblitarated ownership statement and an obliterated oval stamp on fol. 1a.|Ownership statement in the name of Seyit Yahya el-Şüküfi el-Meraşî, dated 1200 (1785-86) and accompanied by his stamp, on fol. ib.|Ownership statement in the name of Seyit Mustafa ibn Ahmet ibn Abdulnafi, known as Tatar Efendi, on fol. 1a, accompanied by two completely oblitared small octagonal stamps.

note: Ms. codex.|Title supplied by the cataloger.|17 lines per page. Written in small taʻlīq in black ink with some use of red. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Glazed European paper.|Ms. additions: extensive additions in later hands before and after the main text, on fol. 2b-11a and fol. 158a-178b, the latter section containing many blank sheets in between the additions. The additions are chiefly verses of poetry and include excerpts from Yunus Emre, Nevʻî, Fuzulî and Veysî. In the main work, the text abruptly stops on fol. 49a and then continues on fol. 53b, with pages in between left chiefly blank, except for three which are again filled with verse additions in a later hand, one of them (on fol. 50a) entitled Mesnevi-yi Baki. Fol. 9a contains several dates, the earliest of which is 27 of Jumādá al-Ākhirah 1143 (1731).|Several ownership stamps in the name of Ahmet and one in the name of Mustafa on fol. 99a; another one in the name of Mustafa on fol. 151a, (dated Rajab '126?); and another in the name of Ahmet on fol. 152a.

The colophon also has a reading statement in the name of Ahmet ibn ... [?] Solak.|17 lines per page. Written in a medium small vocalised naskh in black ink with use of red for rubrication. Text is written in two columns inside a double line frame in red ink. On fol. 2b-5a the text frames are in gold leaf outlined in black ink, and on fol. 2b-3a with an additional line in red ink. Fol. 1b has an illumnated head piece (ʻunwān), consisting of a flower pattern in gold ink and red, green and yellow watercolors, with the title in gold ink in the middle and a medallion in blue watercolor above it. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Thick glazed cream paper with visible chain lines and watermarks. A couple of inscriptions on fol. 2a.|Stamp of "Maktabat al-ʻArab" bookshop of Shaikh Yūsuf Tūmā al-Bustānī, Egypt, on fol. 285b.|Statement of gift from Yūsuf Tūmā al-Bustānī to John Owen, dated 25/7/1935 on fol. 2a.|From the estate of John Owen of Washington, Iowa (two ownership stamps, on front pastedown and fol. 1a.).

physical_description: Extent: 63 leaves : paper ; 119 x 85 (85 x 52) mm. bound to 120 x 90 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title supplied by the cataloger.|7 lines per page. Written in a medium large naskh in black ink with use of red. Text is written inside a single line frame in red ink. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Glazed paper with visible laid, and occasionally visible, uneven chain lines. The text on fol. 47a-49b (part of "Dua-yi ism-i azım") is more decorative and is written inside a frame outlined in several lines in black, red and blue, in the following form: one line of text, followed by several lines inside a circle outlined in blue on yellow colored background, followed by another line of text. Some water damage and loss of text.

physical_description: Extent: ii, 51 leaves : paper ; 194 x 128 (140 x 70) mm. bound to 194 x 128 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. iib (other title from colophon).|Copying/writing (possibly an authograph?) completed on the 22nd of Muḥarram 1206 (1791) -- colophon (fol. 47b).|17 lines per page. Written in a neat, small naskh in black ink with use of red for rubrication. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Glazed European paper with watermarks. Fol. ii (i.e. the first page of the text) is a later replacement in a different, very casual hand. The text ends on fol. 47b, and is followed by three fol. (fol. 48a-50b) of small additions in the same hand, consisting of a couple of prayers (duʻāʾs) and several short excerpts from different works.

physical_description: Extent: 30 leaves : paper ; 220 x 152 (166 x 94) mm. bound to 222 x 156 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 1b.|Copied by Mehmet, known as Sufi Dede, resident of the Koca Mustafa Paşa Hanegah (Istanbul?) and completed on the 25th of Rabīʻ al-Awwal 1242 (1826) -- colophon (fol. 4a).|21 lines per page. Written in a medium sized naskh in black and red ink (the script inside the tables in smaller). The text (and the tables) are inside a double line frame in red ink. On fol. 1b-2a the frames are in gold leaf outlined in black ink. Fol. 1b has an illuminated head piece in gold with green, blue and red watercolors. Catchwords present in the narrative section of the work. Glazed European paper.

note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 2b.|Copied in Istanbul in 1039 (1629 or 1630) by Mehmet Arifî ibn Hasan ibn Abdurrahman, who compared his copy with the author's own copy -- colophon (fol. 99b).|25 lines per page. Written in a medium small nastaʻlīq in black ink with use of red for rubrication. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Glazed (European?) paper. Fol. 1a has several short inscriptions in different hands, one dated 1199 (1784-85). Fol. 2a has an excerpt, as a dedication to the author, by Şeyh Mehmet Efendi ibn İlyas, known as Çivizade, i.e. the Şeyhulislam Çivizade Mehmet Efendi, copied from a copy copied from the original in his own hand. Fol. 2b has another dedication at the head of the page by Mahmut bin Fazlullah bin Mahmut. Both of these are in the scribe's hand.|Ownership statement on fol. 1a in the name of Mir Mehmet Paşa, dated 1267 (1850-1851).|Ownership statement on fol. 2a in the name of Seyit Mehmet Emin.|Originally acquired by Robert Garrett from Abraham Shalom Yahuda ; 1942.|Acquired from Abraham Shalom Yahuda.|Acquired from Abraham Shalom Yahuda.

physical_description: Extent: 101 leaves : paper ; 194 x 132 (138 x 92) mm. bound to 194 x 140 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 3b.|17 lines per page. Written in a medium sized, fairly casual naskh in black ink. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Glazed European paper with watermarks. subject_as_recorded: Turkish poetry--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: 133 leaves : paper ; 214 x 124 (156 x 70) mm. bound to 214 x 128 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 9b.|19 lines per page. Written in a small nastaʻlīq in black ink with use of red for rubrication. Text is written inside a single line frame in red ink, with columns and verses also separated with lines in red ink. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Glazed paper with visible chain lines. The text is on fol. 9b-102b. From fol. 88 onwards is a later replacement on different paper, frame-ruled and with watermarks, and the ms. is finished in a different, more casual hand in black ink only with no text frames. Same frame-ruled paper is at the start (fol. 1-8). Pagination in Arabic numerals in red and black ink. Fol. 1b has a selection of verses in the same hand as the end of the divan. These are dated: 6 Muḥarram 1136 (1723) and 1139 (1726-27). Fol. 2a has a prayer in a different hand. Fol. 3a-4a has short excerpts of text, also in a different hand. Fol. 4b-7b are blank. Fol. 8a has beginning of a prayer (duʻāʾ). Fol. 9a has two short inscription in two different hands. Fol. 103b has text of a letter. Fol. 104a-130b are blank. Fol. 132a and fol. 133a-b have more short inscriptions.|Originally acquired by Robert Garrett from Abraham Shalom Yahuda ; 1942.

physical_description: Extent: 94 leaves : paper ; 204 x 125 (142 x 70) mm. bound to 204 x 125 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title supplied by the cataloger from the label on the inside of upper cover.|19 lines per page. Written in small taʻlīq in black ink. Up to and including fol. 46b there are text frames in red ink, from 47a-75a there are no text frames, fol. 75b-85b have text frames in red ink, and fol. 86a-89b (end of text) have text frames in black ink. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Glazed paper with visible chain lines and prominent pulp. Short inscriptions on fol. 1a and fol. 90a-91b (chiefly additional verses of poetry). Fol. 2a has a faint circular stamp with scalloped edges. Fol. 90b has an inscription signed "Mustafa bende" on a piece of paper pasted to the sheet as a patch repair. Water and wear damage to the paper throughout. Extensive repairs to fol. 75.|Originally acquired by Robert Garrett from Abraham Shalom Yahuda ; 1942.

Inserts.|Collation: Paper ; fol. 139 ; catchwords present only for longer texts ; foliation in red ink using Hindu-Arabic numerals ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Layout: Number of lines varies considerably ; some folios frame-ruled in red.|Description: Most of the MS is written in a similar hand in a small script which at times changes to nastaʻlīq, in black ink with use of red|Origin: According to the note on fol. 1a, following the title and table of contents, the compilation was completed on the first of Jumādá al-Ākhirah 1238 (1823). physical_description: Extent: i, 249 leaves : paper ; 216 x 152 (154 x 86) mm. bound to 216 x 152 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Both titles from the introduction (fol. 9b and 10a).|Composed or copied in Medina in Rajab 1205 (1791)? - this is possibly the author's own copy: other copies do not have the same ending signed Şanizade Mehmet Sadık -- see end of text/colophon.|19 lines per page. Written in a small shikastah-nastaʻlīq in black ink with use of red for rubrication. The text is written inside a double line frame in red ink. On fol. 9b-10a the frames are in gold leaf outlined in black ink. Fol. 9b has a small head piece in gold ink. Glazed European paper. Fol. 1b-8a have a contents grid outlined in two lines of red ink, filled only up to fol. 4b.|Ms. additions:|Text has heavily annotated margins throughout, much of it in the same hand.|Short inscriptions on fol. ia, 1a, 8b, 9a, 248b and 249b, in several different hands.|The main text ends on fol. 236a and is followed by 3 texts of wedding sermons (in Ottoman) on fol. 236b-237a, and then by a copy of an Imperial bequest document (vakfiye) on fol. 237b-248a. All of these are in similar hand and could be additions by the scribe/author. Fol. 8b has a copy of an Imperial order (hatt-i hümayun) in the same hand.|Ms. has 6 loose sheets inside the covers, consisting of fragments from other mss, copies of letters and another copy of an Imperial order (hatt-i hümayun), the latter being in the same hand as in the main ms.|Ownership statement in the name of Abdülkadir ibn Mehmet Emin, accompanied by his stamp, on fol. 9a.|Ownership statement in the name of Seyit Mehmet Tevfik ibn Ahmet Şukrî, dated '68, i.e. 1268 (1851-2), on fol. 9a.|Ownership statement in the name of Seyit Ahmet Ramiz, son of Seyit Mehmet Tevfik ibn Ahmet Şukrî, dated '318 (1900-1), on fol. 9a.|Originally acquired by Robert Garrett from Abraham Shalom Yahuda ; 1942.|Acquired from Abraham Shalom Yahuda.|Acquired from Abraham Shalom Yahuda.|Acquired from Abraham Shalom Yahuda.

subject_as_recorded: Tirmidhī, Muḥammad ibn ʻĪsá, -892. Shamāʼil|Muḥammad, Prophet, -632--Biography--Early works to 1800|Hadith--Commentaries--Early works to 1800|Hadith--Criticism, interpretation, etc.--Early works to 1800|Turkish poetry--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton|Manuscripts, Arabic--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: 92 leaves : paper ; 206 x 145 (135 x 80) mm. bound to 208 x 150 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 1a.|Copied by "zade-yi Köprülüzade" (the son of Köprülüzade?) Seyit Mehmet Nafi el-müderris, and completed on the 2nd of Dhū al-Ḥijjah 1225 (1810) -- colophon (fol. 91b).|17 lines per page. Written in a small nastaʻlīq in black ink with use of red for rubrication. Text is written inside a gold leaf frame outlined in black ink, with columns and separate couplets also divided with lines in gold leaf outlined in black ink. Text frames on fol. 2b-3a are double with additional lines in red ink. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Glazed European paper. Ms. has marginal annotations, mostly excerpts from Qārī al-Harawī's commentary on Shamāʾil, Jamʻ al-wasāʾil fī sharḥ al-Shamāʾil. These are in the same hand as the main text, written in a very small nastaʻlīq in black and red ink to form different shapes including crescent moon, minaret, swords, cups and bowls, fruit, trees, palm-trees etc.|Ownership statement on fol. 1a in red ink in the name of Seyit Mustafa Zihni, known as İmamzade.|Originally acquired by Robert Garrett from Abraham Shalom Yahuda ; 1942.|Acquired from Abraham Shalom Yahuda.

Short inscriptions on fol. 1a, 2a and 153b-154b (prayers, invocations, quotations etc.). Water damage to the paper and some repairs.

subject_as_recorded: Turkish poetry--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: i, 24, ii leaves : paper ; 176 x 122 (140 x 90) mm. bound to 176 x 125 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 1b.|Copied by Osman Kemamî in 1262 (1846) -- colophon (fol. 24a). Following this is a note (in the same hand) about saying a prayer for the author, ending in the date :"sene 1152" (1739-40) [?].|10 lines per page. Written in a medium small ruqʻah in black ink with use of red for rubrication. Fol. 1b has a simple text frame outlined in black and gold ink. Fol. 15b-16a have single line text frames in red ink. Throughout, the text is written in two columns, diagonally. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Glazed European paper. Fol. 1a and 24b both have additional verses written in the same hand. Few short inscriptions on front and back endleaves. "Divani Nefi" written in pencil on the recto of front flyleaf.

note: Ms. codex.|Title supplied by the cataloger.|11 lines per page. Written in a combination of medium and very large vocalised naskh in black ink with use of red. The text is written inside a text frame, outlined in black ink and divided into five sections, starting with one line in very large naskh, followed by four lines of medium naskh, then another line of very large naskh, followed by another four lines of medium naskh, and ending with one line of very large naskh. Fol. 1b has a simple rectangular gold leaf head piece with a heading in red ink (almost completely rubbed out). Glazed European paper. Kabīkaj on fol. ia.|Ownership statement on fol. 1a in the name of Mustafa ibn Ahmet, known as Mollazade el-Köstendilî, accompanied by a stamp.

subject_as_recorded: Bektashi--Doctrines--Early works to 1800|Sufism--Doctrines--Turkey--Early works to 1800|Sufi poetry, Turkish--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: 52 leaves : paper ; 178 x 114 (135 x 72) mm. bound to 180 x 118 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 1b.|Copied by Seyit Ali Rıza and completed in Shaʻbān 1272 (1856) -- colophon (fol. 46a).|17 lines per page. Written in a medium small nastaʻlīq in black ink with use of red for rubrication. Text is written inside a double line frame in red ink. On fol. 1b the text frame is in wide gold leaf outlined in black and red ink. Fol. 1b has and illuminated head piece (ʻunwān): a floral design in green, blue, purple, yellow and brown watercolors with embossed gold leaf trimmings, surrounding the title in red ink. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Dark cream wove paper. The main text ends on fol. 46a and is followed by excerpts of Viranî's poetry (in the same hand ) on fol. 46b-48b. Fol. 49a-52a have the text frames in red ink but are blank. Inscription in pencil on the recto of front flyleaf: "Vîranî Abdul, work on Bektaşî order", and "ZNG 79" and "Ex 516" on inside of upper cover, also in pencil. Ownership statement, in pencil, on fol. 1a in the name of Mustafa ... [?].

subject_as_recorded: ʻAṭṭār, Farīd al-Dīn, -approximately 1230. Pandnāmah|Manuscripts, Turkish--New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: 110 leaves : paper ; 206 x 138 (132 x 70) mm. bound to 208 x 140 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from a later addition in pencil on fol. 6a. Other titles supplied by the cataloger.|Copied by the author Mustafa Şemi and completed on the first of Rajab 996 (1588) -- colophon (fol. 106a).|17 lines per page. Written in a small elegant, fully vocalised naskh in black ink with use of red for rubrication. First 9 fol. have text frames in gold leaf outlined in black ink. The rest is without text frames. Fol. 6b has an elegant illuminated head piece, executed in gold leaf with blue and orange watercolors. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Dark cream glazed paper with visible chain lines. Many short inscriptions (chiefly verses of poetry) on fol. 1a-6a, and few on fol. 106b-110b. One of the inscriptions on fol. 1a has the place, Istanbul, and date 1117 (1705-6). Several inscriptions on fol. 2a are dated 1123 (1711-12). Four stamps, one on fol. 1a, two very faint on fol. 5a, and one on fol. 5b.|Originally acquired by Robert Garrett from Abraham Shalom Yahuda ; 1942.

subject_as_recorded: Qurʼan--Geography--Early works to 1800|Encyclopedias and dictionaries, Turkish--Early works to 1800|Astronomy--Religious aspects--Islam--Early works to 1800|Astronomy--Islamic Empire--Early works to 1800|Islam--Doctrines--Early works to 1800|Sufism--Doctrines--Early works to 1800|Creation (Islam)--Early works to 1800
physical_description: Extent: xiii, 416 leaves : paper ; 292 x 198 (236 x 120) mm. bound to 300 x 205 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. ia.|Copied by Mehmet Emin el-Karamânî el-Uryanîzade, a pupil of Osman -- colophon (fol. 414b). The ms. includes the colophon of the copy from which this one was made: copy by Mehmet bin Ali from Erzurum ["Erzen el-Rûm"], completed in Rabīʻ al-Awwal 1207 (1792) -- fol. 413b, and a copy of a letter by İbrahim Hakkı "to some of his fellow dervishes" included by the second copiest between the two colophons (fol. 413b-414b).|35 lines per page. Written in a medium sized naskh in black ink with use of red for rubrication. The text is written inside a gold leaf frame outlined in black ink. Fol. xiiib-1a have an additional wide gold leaf frame outlined in red, and fol. xiiib has a large illuminated head piece executed in gold leaf with blue, red, yellow, pink, and orange watercolors. The text has many color illustrations, in watercolors and with illuminations, including astrological charts, maps, and theological diagrams. Catchwords start on fol. 150b and carry on until the end of text on the verso of each leaf. Glazed European paper, some sheets colored yellow. Fol. ib-iia have a table of contents inside a grid outlined in black ink. Fol. iib-xiib have the same contents grid but unfilled. A large square ownership stamp on fol. 414b, almost completely obliterated but with date visible: 1223 (1808-9) (traces of the same stamp visible in several other places throughout the ms, but these are completely obliterated).

On fol. 1b-2a the frames are further outlined with a line of blue, and fol. 1b has an illuminated head piece in gold leaf with blue, orange, white and green watercolors. Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Glazed paper with watermarks, variously stained from light yellow to red. Few short inscriptions on fol. 1a (chiefly verses).|Ownership statement on fol. 216b in the name of Mustafa Hamdi, a nephew of Alipaşazade, dated 2nd of Jumādá al-Ūlá 1205 (1791) and accompanied by two stamps in his name.|Originally acquired by Robert Garrett from Abraham Shalom Yahuda ; 1942.|Acquired from Abraham Shalom Yahuda.

First 16 mm. backed by brown leather with gilded fillets, which serves as a protective cover when rolled up; recto is a drawing of a crescent moon within a gold circle.
